title: John Lee (government official)
text:
John Lee Ka-chiu, (; born 7 December 1957) is a <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> government official and former police officer serving as the current <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20for%20Administration">Chief Secretary for Administration</a>, the second senior position in <a href="Government%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong government</a> since 25 June 2021. Lee previously served as <a href="Secretary%20for%20Security">Secretary for Security</a>, Under Secretary for Security and Deputy Commissioner of Police.
Career.
Police officer.
In 1977, at the age of 20, Lee joined the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Police%20Force">Royal Hong Kong Police Force</a> as a probationary inspector. He later became chief superintendent in 1997, assistant commissioner in 2003, senior assistant commissioner in 2007 and deputy commissioner in 2010. Having served in a wide range of operational duties, including the <a href="Criminal%20Investigation%20Department%23Hong%20Kong">CID</a>, Complaints Against Police, Service Quality, Personnel, Training, Information Systems, Finance, Policies Formulation, Planning and Development, Lee had been the Commander of Kowloon West Region, Assistant Commissioner (Crime) and Director of Crime and Security, and Deputy Commissioner (Management).
During his tenure as a police officer, Lee was known to have obtained a <a href="Master%20of%20Public%20Policy%20and%20Administration">master's degree in Public Policy and Administration</a> from <a href="Charles%20Sturt%20University">Charles Sturt University</a> in <a href="Australia">Australia</a> under a self-learning programme sponsored by the force.
Security Bureau.
Lee was appointed Under Secretary for Security in 2012 by <a href="Chief%20Executive%20of%20Hong%20Kong">chief executive</a> <a href="Leung%20Chun-ying">Leung Chun-ying</a> and promoted to <a href="Secretary%20for%20Security">Secretary for Security</a> in July 2017 in <a href="Carrie%20Lam%20as%20Chief%20Executive%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Carrie Lam's administration</a>.
On 3 July 2020, the Chinese state-run <a href="Xinhua%20News%20Agency">Xinhua News Agency</a> stated that the Committee for Safeguarding National Security of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region was formally established. There were 10 members of the committee. As the Secretary for Security of Hong Kong, Lee was a member of the committee.
In October 2020, Lee told Shenzhen Satellite TV in an interview that he was thankful for Beijing pushing through the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20national%20security%20law">National Security Law</a>.
In December 2020, Lee defended the freezing of bank accounts belonging to former legislator <a href="Ted%20Hui">Ted Hui</a>, and said that other bank accounts, including those of suspect's relatives, could be frozen if they were believed to be related to a crime. 
In January 2021, after the arrest of 53 pro-democracy figures, Lee stated to the Legislative Council that they were arrested for "subverting state power." Lee also stated that "The Security Bureau strongly reaffirms and fully supports the Police's operation, which is resolute and professional." In addition, Lee stated that the opposition figures' attempts were "evil" and meant to "overthrow" the government. 
On 15 January 2021, Lee said that the new National Security Law would include police surveillance of communications, potentially giving the police more power to intercept and read communications.
In April 2021, Lee said that Hong Kong's disciplined services would adopt <a href="People%27s%20Liberation%20Army">PLA</a>-style marching in order to demonstrate "nationalistic sentiments" and to "strengthen awareness of national security." 
Chief Secretary.
On 25 June 2021, the HKSAR Government announced that the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">State Council</a> has on the recommendation of the <a href="Chief%20Executive%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">Chief Executive</a> appointed Lee as <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20for%20Administration">Chief Secretary for Administration</a>, making him the third former police officer after <a href="William%20Caine%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">William Caine</a>, the founding <a href="Commissioner%20of%20Police%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">head</a> of the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Police%20Force">Hong Kong Police Force</a> who served as <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20for%20Administration">Colonial Secretary</a> from 1846 to 1854, and <a href="Francis%20Henry%20May">Francis Henry May</a>, Captain Superintendent of the Police Force from 1893 to 1901, and Colonial Secretary from 1902 to 1911, to have taken this role as the most senior minister in government.
In January 2022, after the arrest of employees from <a href="Stand%20News">Stand News</a>, Lee said that US media groups should support law enforcement, claiming that "If you are genuinely interested in press freedom, you should support actions against people who have unlawfully exploited the media as a tool to pursue their political or personal gains".
Personal life.
Lee had surgery to remove <a href="plane%20warts">plane warts</a> from his neck.
Lee's wife and two children hold U.K. citizenship, and therefore Lee is eligible to claim U.K. citizenship as well.
Lee was awarded the <a href="Silver%20Bauhinia%20Star">Silver Bauhinia Star</a> by the Hong Kong SAR Government in 2017.
United States sanctions.
In August 2020, Lee and ten other officials were sanctioned by the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Treasury">United States Department of the Treasury</a> under <a href="Executive%20Order%2013936">Executive Order 13936</a> by <a href="Presidency%20of%20Donald%20Trump">President Trump</a> for undermining Hong Kong's autonomy. He owns a flat at King's Park Villa in <a href="Ho%20Man%20Tin">Ho Man Tin</a>, bought in 1997 for HK $12.5 million and fully paid off, eliminating possible issues from his bank and the US sanctions.
On 14 October 2020, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20State">United States Department of State</a> released a report on 10 individuals who materially contributed to the failure of China to meet its obligations under the Sino–British Joint Declaration and Hong Kong's Basic Law. Lee was on the list.
